text: DevNet is now paused.
<@U03HMUTQ5F0> how long is the downtime?

Yes, of course!

We have an S3 bucket with encryption enabled using a customer KMS key.

To backup the node identities, we do the following:
1. Create temporary RAMFS storage
2. Export node identities to JSON
3. Create tar archive
4. Encrypt archive using the onboarding key, which is stored in Parameter Store (Secret) encrypted with another customer KMS key
5. Upload to S3
6. Clean up and unmount temporary RAMFS storage
This is all automated.

text: When running a validator in docker compose, what's the preferred way to expose the ledger API to other machines? My first thought was to expose port 5001 from the validator container, but looking over start.sh script and supporting files I don't see an obvious way to do that without patching files in place, which really feels like I'm doing it the wrong way.

text:
i got similar issue(forgot the `-M` and i solve as before).

1. bring down every thing
2. bring up only postgres
3. get into psql console, drop the `participant-5 db`
4. bring down it
5. bring up everything again. this time with `-M`
6.  Then it will initialize new db with right old party hint.

text: Still getting the same error

would check the migration dump to see if it is really existed etc.

to setup a new devnet node, you can just nuke the volume out. and starting out from scratch

```docker volume rm compose_postgres-splice```
Then starting with a new party hint and onboarding secret.

You need `-M` to perform the migration, so the old identity is preserved.

I'm not sure why it did't work for you. When I got the error above step are what I did and come backup healthy.

When you starting from scratch, you don't need `-M`. But make sure all volumes are delete. There is also volume ` domain-upgrade-dump` beside the `postgres-splcie` volume.

text: Would you elaborate on this?
